> Really?
>
> The main reason why I write tests is to make sure that no
regressions will
> happen. From the point where I submit my tests, I know that no
matter what
> code gets checked in after me, the functionality of the system will not
> decrease.
>
> Tests also help a great deal make my code more robust.
>
> But drive my design with tests? That's dangerous and can potentially
lead to
> micro-design, i.e. design without seeing the big picture ("I'll use this
> signature because the test looks cleaner then").

I agree with Joakim Ohlrogge; a biggest benefit of use TDD is guide
your design. That's mean a simple way to the problem solution; is very
ease to be lost in a world of designer possibilities; with TDD you
don't open the Pandora Box, you just solve the problem and than make
looks better with refactorization. For me, is in the last step that we
use a designer knowledge like Patterns, OO and so on.
